Hi,

Can you test?:

Servlets - Yes, there are extensions to JUnit that make this trivial. 
The two favorite extensions for this kind of testing are Mock Objects
(mockobjects.com) and Cactus (jakarta.apache.org/cactus).  Once you
understand how these extensions work, it's simple to write test cases
for servlets.

JSP Pages - That depends on what you're trying to test.  Do you have
scriptlets with Java code in your JSP pages?  If yes, then get them
out and implement them as custom tags or servlets/actions.  Then you
will be able to test that code.  Again here, mock objects and cactus
will be a big help.

EJBs - Yes, and Cactus will help you the most to unit test them as is.
 If you refactor the business logic out of the EJBs into POJOs, then
you can rely more on straight JUnit, but will most likely benefit from
using mock objects to help you out.

I would recommend reading JUnit in Action and/or Pragmatic Unit
Testing.  This will give you a good understanding of automated unit
testing.  I haven't read JB's book JUnit Recipes (yet), so I can't in
all honesty recommend it, but I imagine it will be helpful.

Hope this helps...

-Larry
